title: CTRL0000916068 - Transcribed Interview of Steven Mnuchin, (July 18, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held in Room 5480, O'Neill House Office
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
SENIOR COUNSELOR TO THE VICE CHAIR
interview conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
on the United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
Could you please state your full name and spell your last name for the record?
investigative counsel to the select committee.
I understand you're represented by counsel.
Counsel, if you could also introduce yourselves and spell your last names for us.
Steven Peikin, P-e-i-k-i-n, from Sullivan & Cromwell.
Alex Willscher, W-i-1-1-s-c-h-e-r, from Sullivan & Cromwell.
Miles Greene, G-r-e-e-n-e, from Sullivan & Cromwell.
This will be a staff-led interview, although members of the committee may join
put their camera on and I will do my best, Secretary Mnuchin, to indicate when they are
present and recognize them if they choose to be.
know who's on and who's not.
Because it is a virtual interview, members, if they join, will
I'll announce their presence so you
There is an official reporter -- two official reporters -- who will be transcribing the
Please wait until each question is complete before you begin
your response, and we'll try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses such as shaking of your
head, so it's important that you answer each question with an audible verbal response.
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
the question is not clear, please ask for clarification.
And if you don't know the answer,
I have to remind you, as we do with all witnesses, that it is unlawful to deliberately
Doing so could be a violation of 18 U.S.C. 1001 or
So let me start, Secretary Mnuchin, by just show you what we'll mark here as
exhibit No. 1, which is a letter dated today from Special Counsel to the President Richard
Sauber to your lawyers, Mr. Peikin and Mr. Willscher.
Have you seen this in advance and had an opportunity to review it?
I just saw it when I arrived, and I've reviewed it.
It is a letter, for the record, from the White House counsel
indicating that, in their view, it would not be appropriate to assert executive privilege on
the subjects identified, including events within the White House on or about January 6th,
attempts to use the Department of Justice to advance a false narrative that the 2020
election was tainted by widespread fraud, other efforts to alter election results or
So, again, for the record, that's the position of the current White House counsel.
Secretary Mnuchin, you're here voluntarily, correct?
Not pursuant to a subpoena but here, rather, to provide your voluntary
You served as Secretary of Treasury from, my understanding, February of 2017 all
the way through the end of the administration in January 2021.
At any point after the 2020 election, did you have any discussions
with President Trump about the results, the integrity of the vote, or anything having to do
I had a brief conversation with President Trump shortly after the election, so
not long after, and asked him if he was going to concede the election.
was going to pursue his legal remedies before he decided to do anything, which I
And that was the extent of our conversation.
About approximately when did that conversation take place?
It was in the first week.
It may have been a few days, but it was definitely within the first week.
Do you know if it was before or after the election had been called or
I think that was on Saturday the 7th that they projected
My guess is it had been after it had been called, but I don't recall specifically.
Was that in person or by telephone?
I believe it was by telephone.
Is it the only conversation with him at any time that you had
It was the only conversation that I had about the election.
been other times where he said certain things about the election which were consistent
But the only time you recall a direct conversation with him
Did you in any way make an effort to form your own opinion about these
You know, unlike the previous campaign, I was not involved in this campaign.
I was really not in a position to understand things.
Attorney General and other things that he was saying.
So, you know, I followed the
The Attorney General on December the 1st made a public
announcement, did not see -- the Department of Justice did not see existence of election
fraud sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome in any State.
Did you endorse that or believe that to be -- that was accurate?
I had no expertise in understanding anything different, so I respected his
view and assumed that he was correct.
You mentioned before that that first conversation with President
Trump did involve some discussion of whether he would concede.
It was a very brief discussion, but yes.
So no other conversations with him about whether he should concede after
Did you have any concerns -- we've heard from other colleagues of
yours in the Cabinet that they had concerns about the nature of the advice that the
President was getting after the election.
Did you share those concerns, have any reason to believe he was not being served
by other voices outside of the Cabinet?
Again, only from what I was hearing secondhand.
What were you hearing secondhand and what
That there were people around him who were not necessarily the staff or
the full-time people who had been part of the team that were making claims of election
Did you talk with the President at all about that, about --
the advice the President was getting?
Did you express those concerns to anyone else, about the quality of
I may have expressed that to the chief of staff, Mark Meadows, but beyond
On the issue of concession, did you ever talk to Mr. Meadows
about whether the President should or shouldn't concede?
Anyone else besides the President himself, discussions about
I understand on January 6th you were traveling abroad, correct?
When did you first have indication that there was violence at the
Capitol, and how did you get that information?
I came back from dinner, and we turned on the TV and we watched it.
was the first time I had any indication of it.
When you first had the indication of it, did you take any action, make any
Again, it was very late at night.
I definitely didn't speak to the President and didn't speak to Mr. Meadows at
Obviously, I had concerns about what was going on, but I don't recall making
Did you speak to anyone at the White House, for example?
Not the President, not Mr. Meadows?
How about within your own organization, within the Treasury, did
you call back to see if the events were in any way causing concern or affecting the
I was in regular communication with the Treasurer, and it was not impacting
So did you have any concerns about a security threat to the
I had the Secret Service with me, and, you know, they would advise me if
there was such a situation, and we did not have any of those concerns.
How about discussions with anyone at Treasury or elsewhere
about the stability of financial systems or markets, either on or after January 6th, did you
have any of those concerns or discussions?
I did not have those concerns.
There were plenty of other times that I had those concerns while I was in
office and we appropriately dealt with them, but the markets were functioning normally.
Did you have any conversations with Vice President
I had no conversations with him that day.
Tell us about that conversation after January 6th and the election
Tell us about any conversations you had with Vice President Pence.
Again, I had a normal conversation with him just to check in, given the
Tell us what you said to him and what he said back to you.
Again, I wanted to make sure that he was okay.
about the normal functioning of government.
Did he say anything, share anything with you about his experience or
I appreciated what he did, but I don't -- I don't specifically remember that
Did you express thanks or admiration or compliment him on the steps that
He did not go into the details.
I obviously had read a bunch of it in the
We'll talk a little bit more here about efforts, discussions about
things to do and some of the transition.
Anything at all, though, with Vice President Pence about the events of the 6th?
How about military leaders or Members of Congress, did you ever speak to
any of them about the events of the 6th?
I don't recall speaking to Members of Congress, I think only because in one
of the questions that you sent me you referenced that General Milley referenced a
conversation that he and myself and Secretary Pompeo had had.
Do you recall a conversation where General
Milley was present where you were talking to Secretary Pompeo?
having seen him other than that period of time.
conversation on the sidelines of that.
I believe -- I believe it must have been a meeting, a normal meeting in the
It was probably a Principals Committee meeting, because I don't recall
And we may have had a casual
And do you recall anything specific about that casual conversation?
Again, I recall that, you know, we felt there was the normal functioning of
And, again, putting aside the election issues, we all had a lot to do and
Let me just read you what General Milley testified when he was here
He was asked, "Do you remember on the 6th or days thereafter any discussion of
the potential invocation of the 25th Amendment?"
So I'm not a member of the Cabinet and I have no role whatsoever
in the 25th Amendment, but there was at least one or two occasions when other
members of the Cabinet mentioned it very brief, like 10 seconds, 15 seconds.
they looked and they saw that I was standing there and, knowing that I'm not a member
of the Cabinet, they shut up."
General Milley said, "It was just a discussion.
I think that's it, those two."
and then the term '25th Amendment' comes up.
see me, they know I'm not a member of the Cabinet, so they ceased the discussion."
I'm like from here to here
And he literally was about as far as I am from you.
That ring any bells, or do you recall talking to Secretary Pompeo in General
I mean, I do recall speaking to Secretary Pompeo about the 25th
stopped the conversation when General Milley came up.
I don't recall it being in that circumstance, and I surely don't recall that I
Let's talk then about your conversations with Secretary Pompeo or
others about that topic of the 25th Amendment.
Tell me, when was the first time that you had any such discussion, either on or
So I think, as you are aware, kind of during the month of December I was
Again, I just want to put this in perspective on timing.
very, very busy negotiating with Congress both what was the CARES Act and
the additional funding of government, which I believe President Trump signed on
So that was really my full-time focus.
I then ended up leaving shortly for vacation.
planned trip to Egypt, Sudan, and other countries in the Mideast.
And then I went on a
So I believe the conversation that you're referencing must have been, you
know -- we can check the exact date I got back, but it was not in the first few days.
So, again, my conversations with Secretary Pompeo, when I got back, this
So every time you turned on TV, there was the 25th Amendment.
It came up very briefly in our conversation.
We both believed that the best
outcome was a normal transition of power, which was working, and neither one of us
contemplated in any serious format the 25th Amendment.
Did you or anyone on your behalf do any kind of research into the
predicates for the invocation of the act or sort of --
The only research I did out of curiosity was I googled it.
remember my general counsel asking me if we wanted him to do extensive research on it.
I said, no, not at this point.
I see Ms. Lofgren has joined us, a member of the committee.
So you talked to Secretary Pompeo about that prospect?
Again, it came up in a conversation.
I can't recall in date whether it was in
the conversation with General Milley or whether it was in a different conversation that
Do you remember talking about the 25th Amendment with any
other members of the President's Cabinet?
Do you remember talking about it on the telephone in addition to
the in-person discussion that General Milley referenced?
I recall discussing it on the telephone.
were together in the Situation Room.
But, again, it sounds like a meeting where the three of us
Do you recall a telephone conversation with Pompeo about it?
I'm familiar with it, but go ahead.
He said, "Mnuchin did have conversations with other members, plural, of the
Anyone else that you talked to on the phone?
There's a -- let me read you a passage from Jonathan Karl's book.
Cabinet that night, January 6th, and the next morning on a step much more dramatic than
talked to other members of the Cabinet about attempting to remove Trump from office
night was Secretary of State Pompeo."
According to a source familiar with the conversations, Mnuchin
Among the Cabinet officials Mnuchin spoke to that
I can tell you I did speak to Jonathan Karl on
What I told him -- he asked me about the 25th Amendment.
was not going to make any comments on the 25th Amendment, that I didn't think it was
appropriate in that format, and that he shouldn't take that as meaning that there were
He also asked me whether I had a conversation separately with Secretary Pompeo,
and I answered I had spoken to Secretary Pompeo after January 6th, not referencing that
I spoke to him about the 25th Amendment.
So if he has that information from other people, I believe it's inaccurate.
And I take it from your answer, Secretary Mnuchin, that you
never personally formed the view that President Trump was incapable of carrying out the
functions of the office or had mental illness sufficient to trigger invocation of the 25th
Again, I never did the legal research on the 25th Amendment.
putting aside the elections, I believed that he was able to and we did have a normal
Did you ever speak to Vice President Pence or any members of his
So just to be clear, you don't remember any conversations with
Let me ask you about some other steps that were
discussed in the days after January 6th to ensure functioning of government and a
We interviewed Secretary Scalia, and he told us that he thought perhaps a Cabinet
meeting should be convened and that the Cabinet should be more directly involved in big
decisions in the last 2 weeks of the administration.
Do you remember hearing about that or having --
Again, I may have spoken to Scalia during that period.
You didn't talk to Scalia or others?
remember having a conversation as you've described and him saying there should be a
Did anyone raise that prospect with you?
I mean, I would also just say in terms of Cabinet meetings, most of the
functioning of the government that we did was outside of Cabinet meetings.
be a little bit of an odd request.
Were there any discussions about, beyond the 25th Amendment or a
Cabinet meeting, other steps that should be taken to ensure smooth function of
government between January 6th and January 20th that you were involved in yourself?
I'm sorry, give that to me again.
Were there any other steps discussed, that you discussed with anybody else,
about specific things that needed to be done, so in the wake of January 6th, to make sure
that the term was finished appropriately?
Not in the wake of January 6th.
There were other things that were part of
a normal transition that were discussed, things that are similar to any other Presidential
transition, and they were proceeding properly.
Did you ever at any time perceive resistance to cooperating with the
transition, even going back before January 6th, from the White House or anyone else?
So if you recall, I believe it was in late November, the GSA certified the funds
We had been working internally on transition plans before the election,
which is required no matter who wins the election.
We continued to work on them.
And then I believe it was after November 26th or 28th, I forget what the date was,
when that was certified we were told by the White House that we could proceed and
speak to -- in that case, I spoke to Janet Yellen several times.
But it sounds like once that occurred, the funds were appropriated,
there was no -- you never perceived any resistance.
I think that's called ascertainment or something like that.
We had professional career staff who were working
As I said, I had several conversations with Janet Yellen during that period of time.
I see that Mr. Aguilar has joined us as well, a second member of the committee.
So several of your colleagues in the Cabinet did resign, right, on or soon
Did you have any conversations with either Secretary DeVos or
Secretary Chao about their decisions to resign?
best thing I could do to serve the American people was to continue in my job.
we had a lot of work to do in those last 2 weeks.
Do you remember discussions with anyone who didn't resign who
was contemplating it, Cabinet or otherwise, as a result of January 6th?
I'd say everybody else who didn't resign, again, there was a lot of work
going on independent of the election.
of work we were working on right until the very end.
Again, as it relates to the CARES Act, we had a lot
Just going back, looking over my notes, Secretary Mnuchin, you
issued a statement by tweet on the night of January 6th.
I guess it was very late at night
We must respect our Constitution and
It's something that was drafted for you, you drafted yourself?
Typical of these types of tweets, it was a
combination of myself, my communications staff, and other staff members.
And why was it important to use those words or to issue that
was something I was watching on TV.
I was out of the country.
And I thought it was appropriate.
When you say, "We must respect our Constitution and democratic
processes," why -- beyond violence -- why did you feel it necessary to include a reference
to the Constitution and the democratic process?
Again, I thought it was appropriate.
I can't remember the specific things.
But, again, it was -- we thought it was appropriate.
You were able, as a Cabinet Secretary --
But I wouldn't normally have done that.
So, again, no conversations with DeVos or Chao or anyone else about resignations,
Did you clear that or notify the White House in any way before --
You mentioned a conversation with Vice President Pence.
anything else or any other conversations with him that you had, either about January 6th
or about sort of transition or the last 2 weeks?
I just recall one conversation with him during that period of time.
I also wanted to ask you about a name of Jeff Clark.
Jeff Clark, who was a lawyer at the Justice Department?
How do you know Jeff Clark?
I met Jeff Clark -- so let me be clear.
conversations during this period of time with Jeff Clark whatsoever.
socially earlier on, and he was involved in certain areas around animal rights and other
things that we had an interest in.
of, you know, kind of January on.
But I never -- I never spoke to him within the period
So you didn't have any discussions with him about his interest in
I was -- I watched on TV and was surprised.
Certainly no discussions with anyone about him becoming
Discussion with the President about him, did you ever --
Mr. Aguilar or Ms. Lofgren, do you have any questions?
Mr. Mnuchin, I just wanted to go back real quick to your conversations with
So just so I'm clear, did you say there are two separate conversations that you can
recall with Secretary Pompeo, one in the Situation Room and another over the phone,
where the 25th Amendment was brought up?
So, again, I recall the conversation over the phone.
Again, since you've referenced to me and General Milley said, I have no
reason to believe he's not accurate, but I don't remember that conversation.
So you recall one phone conversation?
Do you recall, just generally, the 25th Amendment coming up more than
But the other one may have been the case.
once in conversations that you had during the post-January 6th time period?
Again, what I recall was it was all over the press, and everybody was
tweeting about it, and my name was in a lot of the tweets, again, you know, from the
period I was coming back for the next 1 or 2 days.
in that context and then, no, we didn't discuss it after that.
And, you know, so, again, it came up
And what do you recall Secretary Pompeo saying to you on the topic?
Again, I think we both had the same view, which was, you know, we were
supportive of an orderly transition of government, and we saw the government
functioning and thought that was the best outcome.
And it sounds like he was not of the opinion, from what you could tell, about
Did Secretary Pompeo share with you if he was talking to anyone else about
I think we were both of the opinion at that time that the best thing was to
proceed with a normal transition of power.
Have you talked to President Trump since you both left office January the
Have you talked to him at all about January 6th?
How about about your testimony today?
I don't want to hear about your conversations with them, but have you talked to anyone
else about the fact that you were going to be here talking to us today?
I told my wife and I told people in my office today in case this leaked into the
But sort of on the merits, any
-- anyone else about the subject matter of your testimony?
Did anyone in any way try
to influence your testimony, encourage you to do or not do certain things when you
And, again, I just want to clarify one thing since I did reach out to
Secretary Pompeo to get his lawyer's information and put our lawyers in touch.
was the extent of my conversation with him about today.
I don't have any other questions.
Mr. Aguilar do not either, then I think we can go off the record.
[Whereupon, at 2:35 p.m., the interview was concluded.]
I have read the foregoing _ _ pages, which contain the correct transcript of the
answers made by me to the questions therein recorded.
